Question 1.Explanation: Bad debt is an expense that a business incurs once the repayment of credit previously extended to a customer is estimated to be uncollectible. Bad debt are irrecoverable debts which are recorded under profit and loss a/c.

Question 5.Question: An entry in a subsidiary book which does not form part of the double entry system is a
Question 5.Explanation: Single entry or complete record does not form part of double entry principle. It is known as an incomplete or unscientific method for recording transaction. Most businesses maintain a record of all transactions using double-entry bookkeeping.

The cash book is correct

Question 6.Explanation: Bank reconciliation statement in single entry incomplete record would ensure that all cash are banked.

Question 7.Question:
I.Fixtures account

II.Machinery account

III.Wages account

IV.Rent account

Which of the above are nominal accounts?
Question 7.Explanation: A nominal account is an income statement account (expenses, income, loss, profit). It is also known as a temporary account, unlike the balance sheet account (Asset, Liability, owner's equity), which are permanent accounts. So nominal accounting starts with a zero balance at the start of every accounting year. Nominal accounts are accounts for income and expenses. i.e. III and IV.

Question 10.Explanation: Discount column differentiated three columns from a two column cash book. Question 12.Explanation: Provision for depreciation is debited to P & L a/c and deducted from the fixed asset in the balance. This account is used to accumulate depreciation that is provided against a fixed asset.

Question 13.Question:
Given:

Rates paid during the year amounted to N 2,250 at N 125 per month and N 1,035 was paid for electricity in the same period at N 115 per month.

Determine the amount of prepaid rates.
Question 13.Explanation:
Rates = N 125 per month

Rate (1 year) = N 125 × 12 = N 1,500

Rate paid = N 2,250

Rate paid in advance = N (2,250 - 1,500) = N 750

Question 17.Question: Accrual accounting differs from cash accounting because it recognizes
Question 17.Explanation: Accrual basis takes into account of both creditors and debtors unlike cash basis which does not. Cash accounting recognizes revenue and expenses only when money changes hands, but accrual accounting recognizes revenue when it's earned, and expenses when they're billed (but not paid).

Question 18.Explanation: Only public company can invite the members of the public to subscribe for its shares. A public company is free to invite public for subscription i.e., a public company can issue a prospectus.
